intro: Widjajachloa, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a member of the Asparagaceae family and is native to New Zealand. It is characterized by its tall, erect stems and long, narrow leaves that can grow up to several meters in length. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are typically green or white in color. Widjajachloa is valued for its strong, fibrous leaves, which have been traditionally used by Māori for weaving and crafting. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in coastal and forested areas.
